topic: Socio Religious Reform Movement, Organisations and Personalities

flashcards.back: Dr. Rakhmabai - Legal battle against child marriage led to Age of Consent Act 1891, became one of first female doctors in colonial India
Women of Kuka Community (Punjab) - Actively participated in protests against British rule, providing significant support
Swarnakumari Devi, Sarala Devi Chaudhurani - Key figures in protests against Partition, played important role in Swadeshi movement
Annie Besant led Home Rule League, Margaret Cousins co-founded Women's Indian Association, advocating women's suffrage across Madras, Maharashtra, Gujarat, UP
Annie Besant, Dorothy Jinarajadasa, Margaret Cousins - Founded in Madras, worked towards women's suffrage and social reforms
Kasturba Gandhi, Sarojini Naidu - Instrumental in protesting Rowlatt Act and participating in Satyagraha against repressive British laws
Basanti Debi - First woman to be arrested for movement. Suniti Devi promoted spinning of khadi and boycott of foreign goods in Bengal
Anasuya Sarabhai - Founded Ahmedabad Textile Labour Association, advocating for labour rights and better working conditions for textile workers
Margaret Cousins - Central figure in founding AIWC, promoted women's education, social rights, economic empowerment
Muthulakshmi Reddi - First woman legislator in Chennai's Legislative Council, crucial role advocating for Sharda Act
Sarojini Naidu led Dharasana Salt Works raid, Mithuben Petit prominent participant in Salt Marches
Santi Ghose, Suniti Chaudhuri - Involved in assassination of British district magistrate, marking entry of women into revolutionary activities
Usha Mehta ran secret Congress Radio, Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay arrested for promoting self-reliance through handicrafts and selling contraband salt

Aruna Asaf Ali hoisted Indian flag at Gowalia Tank, Sucheta Kriplani organised protests, Matangini Hazra became martyr, Kasturba Gandhi participated, Parbati Giri provided humanitarian services, Bina Das attempted Governor assassination
Kalyani Das, Bina Das - Played vital roles in famine relief efforts and contributed to fight for India's independence
Rameshwari Nehru, Mridula Sarabhai - Focused on refugee rehabilitation and women's welfare in Partition aftermath
1916: Co-founded Women's Indian Association. 1917: Founded Women's Indian Association in Madras. 1927: Central figure in founding AIWC
1919: Rowlatt Satyagraha. 1927: AIWC founding member. 1930: Led Dharasana Salt Works raid
1916: Led Home Rule League. 1917: Founded Women's Indian Association with Dorothy Jinarajadasa and Margaret Cousins
1919: Rowlatt Satyagraha. 1942: Quit India Movement participation
1942: Attempted Governor of Bengal assassination. 1943: Famine relief efforts
1905: Key figures in Partition of Bengal protests, important role in Swadeshi movement

mcq.question: Who became martyr in Quit India Movement (1942)?

mcq.question: Who worked on famine relief in 1943 Bengal Famine?

mcq.question: Who worked on refugee rehabilitation post-Partition (1947)?
mcq.explanation: Rameshwari Nehru and Mridula Sarabhai focused on refugee rehabilitation and women's welfare after Partition 1947.

comprehensive.question: Trace women's participation in Indian national movement from Early Feminist Movement (1872) through Independence (1947), analyzing their evolving roles from social reform to active revolutionary participation.
comprehensive.answer: Early Phase - Social Reform (1872-1905): 1872 Early Feminist Movement: Dr. Rakhmabai's legal battle against child marriage led to Age of Consent Act 1891, became one of first female doctors. Legal/educational focus. 1872 Kuka Movement: Women of Kuka Community in Punjab actively participated in anti-British protests - early political participation. 1905 Partition of Bengal: Swarnakumari Devi, Sarala Devi Chaudhurani key figures in protests, important role in Swadeshi movement - women entering nationalist politics. Organized Movements (1916-1927): 1916 Home Rule Movement: Annie Besant led Home Rule League, Margaret Cousins co-founded Women's Indian Association advocating women's suffrage across regions. Formal organizational leadership. 1917 Women's Indian Association: Annie Besant, Dorothy Jinarajadasa, Margaret Cousins founded in Madras for suffrage and social reforms. Institutionalizing women's activism. 1925 Trade Union: Anasuya Sarabhai founded Ahmedabad Textile Labour Association for textile workers' rights. Women's labour movement. 1927 AIWC: Margaret Cousins central in founding All India Women's Conference promoting education, social rights, economic empowerment. Peak of women's organizational capacity. Mass Movements (1919-1930): 1919 Rowlatt Satyagraha: Kasturba Gandhi, Sarojini Naidu instrumental in protesting Rowlatt Act, participating in Satyagraha. Women in mass resistance. 1921 Non-Cooperation: Basanti Debi first woman arrested. Suniti Devi promoted khadi spinning, foreign goods boycott in Bengal. Women facing arrest, participating in economic boycott. 1929 Legislative Reform: Muthulakshmi Reddi, first woman legislator in Chennai's Legislative Council, advocated for Child Marriage Restraint Act (Sharda Act). Women in formal politics. 1930 Salt Satyagraha: Sarojini Naidu led Dharasana Salt Works raid, Mithuben Petit prominent in Salt Marches. Women leading mass civil disobedience. Revolutionary Phase (1930s): 1930s Revolutionary Movement: Santi Ghose, Suniti Chaudhuri involved in assassination of British district magistrate - marking women's entry into revolutionary violence. Breaking gender boundaries in armed struggle. 1930s Civil Disobedience: Usha Mehta ran secret Congress Radio. Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay arrested for promoting self-reliance through handicrafts, selling contraband salt. Underground resistance, alternative economy. Final Push (1942-1947): 1942 Quit India: Aruna Asaf Ali hoisted Indian flag at Gowalia Tank (iconic symbol). Sucheta Kriplani organised protests. Matangini Hazra became martyr. Kasturba Gandhi participated. Parbati Giri provided humanitarian services. Bina Das attempted Governor assassination. Women across spectrum: symbolic leadership (flag hoisting), organizational (protests), martyrdom, humanitarian, revolutionary violence. 1943 Bengal Famine: Kalyani Das, Bina Das vital in famine relief, contributing to independence fight. Humanitarian dimension. 1947 Partition: Rameshwari Nehru, Mridula Sarabhai focused on refugee rehabilitation, women's welfare. Post-independence transition work. Evolution Analysis: Role Expansion: Social reform (Rakhmabai) → Political protests (Kuka, Partition) → Organizational leadership (Besant, Cousins, AIWC) → Mass movements (Non-Cooperation, Salt) → Revolutionary violence (Ghose, Chaudhuri, Bina Das) → Underground resistance (Usha Mehta) → Iconic leadership (Aruna Asaf Ali). From periphery to center of nationalist movement. Risk Escalation: Legal battles → Public protests → Arrests → Leading raids → Armed violence → Martyrdom. Increasing personal risk, challenging gender norms. Organizational Capacity: 1917 Women's Indian Association → 1927 AIWC → Multiple women's organizations. Building institutional frameworks. Class Diversity: Educated elite (Rakhmabai, Sarojini Naidu) → Labour (Anasuya Sarabhai, textile workers) → Rural (Kuka women, Matangini Hazra) → Diverse class participation. Geographic Spread: Punjab (Kuka), Bengal (Swarnakumari, Basanti, Santi/Suniti, Usha, Matangini), Madras (Muthulakshmi, Women's Indian Association), Gujarat (Anasuya, Mithuben), Maharashtra (Kamaladevi), pan-Indian (Sarojini Naidu). All regions participating. Continuity: Margaret Cousins (1916 WIA, 1917 Association, 1927 AIWC). Sarojini Naidu (1919 Rowlatt, 1927 AIWC, 1930 Salt). Kasturba Gandhi (1919 Rowlatt, 1942 Quit India). Bina Das (1942 assassination attempt, 1943 famine relief). Long-term commitment across multiple movements. Significance: Women weren't auxiliary to national movement - they were integral across all phases: social reform, mass mobilization, armed struggle, underground resistance, humanitarian work, post-independence rehabilitation. Their participation challenged both colonial rule and patriarchal norms simultaneously, achieving dual emancipation (national and gendered). By 1947, women had proven capacity for every form of political action: legal activism, mass protest, organizational leadership, revolutionary violence, clandestine resistance, humanitarian service, and post-conflict reconstruction.
